case_name: AL. PR. Periakaruppan Chettiar v. AL. PR. Alagappa Chettiar

facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 104 of 1954 and 169 of 1956 before the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeals Nos. 104 of 1954 and 169 of 1956. Appeal by special leave

facts.text: Appeal No. 104 of 1954 by special leave under Art. 136 from Madras High Court judgment dated November 13, 1950 in A.S. No. 484 of 1947 arising from Subordinate Judge Devakottai judgment dated December 21, 1946 in O.S. No. 156 of 1944.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated November 13, 1950, of the Madras High Court in A. S. No. 484 of 1947 arising out of the judgment and decree dated December 21, 1946, of the

facts.text: Appeal No. 169 of 1956 by certificate under Art. 133(1)(a) from Madras High Court judgments dated September 17, 1952 and October 24, 1952 in A.S. No. 243 of 1947 arising from Subordinate Judge Devakottai judgment dated December 21, 1946 in O.S. No. 164 of 1944.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and decree dated September 17, 1952 and October 24, 1952, of the Madras High Court in A.S. No. 243 of 1947 arising out of the judgment and decree dated December 21, in Original Suit No. 164

facts.text: Parties are Nattukottai Chetties having banking transactions in Burma and South-East Asia.

anchor.surface_text: The parties to the litigation are Nattukottai Chetties, a wealthy banking community in South India who, at the time, were having large banking transactions in Burma and other places in South-East Asia.

facts.text: AL. PR. Periakaruppan Chettiar owned and possessed considerable properties.

anchor.surface_text: One AL. PR. Periakaruppan Chettiar hereinafter referred to as Periakaruppa owned and possessed considerable properties.

facts.text: Periakaruppa adopted AL. PR. Alagappa Chettiar in or about 1914.

anchor.surface_text: He adopted one AL. PR. Alagappa Chettiar hereinafter, referred to as Alagappa in or about the year 1914.

facts.text: Acute differences between Periakaruppa and Alagappa from about 1924 due to Alagappa's wasteful habits and debts.

anchor.surface_text: there arose acute differences between them from about the year 1924 owing to the alleged wasteful habits of Alagappa who ran into debts.

facts.text: Criminal complaints between Periakaruppa and Alagappa in 1926 (Exs. P-5 and D-12).

anchor.surface_text: This led to criminal complaints between them, each against the other, in 1926. See Exs. P-5 and D-12 .

facts.text: One of Alagappa's creditors obtained decree and attached Alagappa's half share in family residential house; suit found site ancestral, superstructure Periakaruppa's self-acquisition (High Court judgment November 19, 1926).

anchor.surface_text: One of Alagappas creditors obtained a decree against him and attached Alagappas half share in the family residential house including the site on which it was situated. ... The judgment of the High Court was dated November 19, 1926

facts.text: Periakaruppa purported to adopt AL. PR. Ranganathan Chettiar on or about June 27, 1926, claiming custom in Nattukottai Chetti families.

anchor.surface_text: It has to be mentioned that in or about June 27, 1926, Periakaruppa purported to make a second adoption of a young boy by name AL. PR. Ranganathan Chettiar hereinafter referred to as Ranganatha

facts.text: Alagappa and minor son junior Periakaruppan filed O.S. No. 114 of 1926 on September 9, 1926 against Periakaruppa and Ranganatha for half share of properties and declaration second adoption invalid.

anchor.surface_text: During the pendency of this litigation in the High Court the adopted son Alagappa filed a suit on September 9, 1926, on behalf of himself and his minor son ... The suit O.S. No. 114 of 1926 filed by Alagappa and his minor son

facts.text: Suit O.S. 114/1926 compromised by Rajinama on August 15, 1927: Alagappa and junior got Rs.75,000 each, Muthayi Achi Rs.14,000; properties admitted self-acquisitions of Periakaruppa, no rights for plaintiffs, vacate house.

anchor.surface_text: Before the suit proceeded to the stage of issues and trial, the dispute between the parties was compromised by a Rajinama ... the compromise was accepted by the court on August 15, 1927, and the suit was dismissed

facts.text: Periakaruppa executed will on April 4, 1929; genuineness not in question.

anchor.surface_text: About a year and a half later Periakaruppa executed a will on April 4, 1929. The genuineness and due execution thereof are not in question.

facts.text: Periakaruppa died on July 14, 1929; wife Lakshmi Achi died March 11, 1930.

anchor.surface_text: Periakaruppa died about three months later i.e. on July 14, 1929, and his wife Lakshmi Achi died within a year thereof on March 11, 1930.

facts.text: Ranganatha in undisputed possession of Periakaruppa's properties since around 1930 till 1944.

anchor.surface_text: Ranganatha, who, some time in or about the date of Lakshmi Achis death in 1930, appears to have attained majority, has been in undisputed possession

facts.text: Junior Periakaruppan attained majority December 1943, filed O.S. 156/1944 and O.S. 164/1944 on November 11, 1944.

anchor.surface_text: Alagappas son junior Periakaruppa attained majority in December, 1943, and filed two suits on November 11, 1944, in the Subordinate Judges Court of Devakottai

facts.text: O.S. 156/1944 (trust suit): Claim Rs.75,000 under Rajinama constituted trust, appropriated by Chockalingam, Periakaruppa liable as co-trustee.

anchor.surface_text: O.S. No. 156 of 1944 was on the footing that Rs. 75,000 which was given to him under the above mentioned Rajinama of the year 1927, was, under the terms thereof constituted a trust

facts.text: O.S. 164/1944 (succession suit): Recover properties from Ranganatha, claiming invalid adoption, ineffective will, devolution to Alagappa and junior.

anchor.surface_text: The second suit O.S. No. 164 of 1944 was a suit to recover the entire properties of Periakaruppa in the possession of Ranganatha ... on the ground that Ranganathas adoption was invalid, that the will of Periakaruppa was ineffective

facts.text: Both lower courts found adoption of Ranganatha invalid (not disputed in Supreme Court).

anchor.surface_text: So far as the adoption of Ranganatha was concerned both the courts below, while holding that the adoption as a fact was proved, have found against existence of the custom pleaded as to its validity

facts.text: Supreme Court held Periakaruppa's will effective, bequeathing residue to Ranganatha as persona designata.

anchor.surface_text: We have, therefore, come to a clear conclusion that Ranganatha notwithstanding his description as adopted son in the will in several places, was intended by the testator to take the property as persona designata

facts.text: Supreme Court held no trust created under Rajinama making Periakaruppa trustee for Rs.75,000.

anchor.surface_text: Learned Judges of the High Court were greatly influenced ... But that does not necessarily mean that Periakaruppa took upon himself the responsibility

facts.text: Out of Rs.75,000 trust amount, Rs.30,000 invested in house purchase at Athangudi on July 23, 1928, occupied by Alagappa family.

anchor.surface_text: It appeared on the evidence that out of the trust amount, a sum of Rs. 30,000/- was invested in the purchase of a house at Athangudi ... on July 23,1928, living in that house.

facts.text: Chockalingam executed mortgage May 3, 1930 for Rs.1,00,000 (Rs.70,000 for junior) on Athangudi house and Burma property.

anchor.surface_text: he Chockalingam appears to have executed of his own accord a simple mortgage dated May 3, 1930, ... for a sum of Rs. 1,00,000 of which Rs. 70,000 was intended to be the plaintiffs money

facts.text: Trial court dismissed succession suit as time-barred; High Court reversed, decreed half share to junior Periakaruppa.

anchor.surface_text: the trial court dismissed the suit as barred by limitation, while the High Court reversed it and granted a decree for the half share of Periakaruppas properties in favour of junior Periakaruppa

facts.text: Supreme Court allowed appeal No. 169/1956, dismissed succession suit.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal, i.e., Civil Appeal No. 169 of 1956, is accordingly allowed with costs throughout and the plaintiffs suit dismissed.
under Art. 136 1  of the Constitution. Civil Appeal No. 169 of 1956 has companye up by reason of certificate
certificate granted by the High Court under Art. 133 1  a  of the Constitution. The parties to the litigation are
barred by virtue of s. 7 of the Limitation Act. A few other minor points have been raised on both sides

arguments.claim: Ranganatha intended by testator to take property as persona designata notwithstanding description as adopted son

anchor.surface_text: We have, therefore, come to a clear conclusion that Ranganatha notwithstanding his description as adopted son in the will in several places, was intended by the testator to take the property as persona designata

arguments.claim: No trust created under Rajinama; Periakaruppa only supervisor (mel parthu), not trustee with control

anchor.surface_text: Learned Judges of the High Court were greatly influenced ... But that does not necessarily mean that Periakaruppa took upon himself the responsibility

holdings.text: The adoption of Ranganatha as a second adopted son was invalid as the custom pleaded was not proved.

anchor.surface_text: So far as the adoption of Ranganatha was concerned both the courts below, while holding that the adoption as a fact was proved, have found against existence of the custom pleaded as to its validity and hence concurrently found the adoption to be invalid. That conclusion is no longer in dispute in this Court.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Lower courts concurrently found custom not proved; Supreme Court accepts without dispute.

holdings.text: The will was effective to convey the property of Periakaruppa to Ranganatha after the death of his wife Lakshmi Achi, notwithstanding the invalidity of his adoption, as Ranganatha was intended to take as persona designata.

anchor.surface_text: We have, therefore, come to a clear conclusion that Ranganatha notwithstanding his description as adopted son in the will in several places, was intended by the testator to take the property as persona designata and that the will was therefore effective to convey title to him to residue of properties left by Periakaruppa after his death,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Construction of will clauses, family history, intent to exclude Alagappa, repeated description as adopted son merely descriptive not conditional; precedents Nidhoomoni and Fanindra applied.

holdings.text: There is an effective dispositive clause in the will and the disposition in favour of Ranganatha was not an attempt to create an estate in tail-male.

anchor.surface_text: We agree with the reasoning of the High Court on these two points and they do not call for any further consideration. We are satisfied that there is no substance in these contentions.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Agrees with High Court reasoning rejecting petitioner's contentions on lack of dispositive clause and invalid tail-male estate.

holdings.text: Under the Rajinama, Periakaruppa and Chockalingam did not become trustees in respect of Rs.75,000; Periakaruppa was not constituted a trustee nor did he act as one.

anchor.surface_text: Learned Judges of the High Court were greatly influenced by the assumption that it could not have been the intention of Periakaruppa to allow a spendthrift like Alagappa to handle the funds of the minor... But that does not necessarily mean that Periakaruppa took upon himself the responsibility

holdings.reasoning_summary: Construction of Rajinama para 3 and hundi terms indicate supervision (mel parthu) not control or trusteeship; contemporaneous acts show guardians handled funds, Periakaruppa uninvolved.

holdings.text: The word 'order' in the Rajinama and hundi does not have the same meaning as under the Negotiable Instruments Act; a deposit receipt is not a negotiable instrument.

anchor.surface_text: A deposit receipt of that kind does not fall within the definition of negotiable instrument under s. 13 of the Negotiable Instruments Act. There is no authority for showing that such a deposit receipt is a document to which the provisions of Negotiable Instruments Act as to the use of the word order

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes hundi from subsequent deposit receipt; NI Act ss.8,9,13 not applicable to deposit receipts per precedents; no proof of maral usage.

holdings.text: Civil Appeal No. 169 of 1956 allowed; succession suit dismissed as barred or on merits due to valid will.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal, i.e., Civil Appeal No. 169 of 1956, is accordingly allowed with costs throughout and the plaintiffs suit dismissed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows from holding on valid will making other issues moot.

anchor.surface_text: is reported in Periakarappan Arunachalam 1 . During the pendency of this litigation in the High Court the adopted son Alagappa filed a suit on September 9, 1926, on behalf of himself and his minor son by name AL. PR. AL. Periakaruppan Chettiar

precedents.cited_proposition: site was ancestral and super-structure was self-acquired property of Periakaruppa

anchor.surface_text: the judgment reported in Periakaruppan Arunachalam 1  was to be withdrawn. This compromise was certified to be for the benefit of the minor plaintiff concerned, as also of the minor defendant Ranganatha and was accepted by the Subordinate Judge before whom the compromise petition was filed.

precedents.cited_proposition: previous judgment whose appeal was to be withdrawn as per Rajinama

anchor.surface_text: 1   1926  I.L.R. 50 Mad. 582, minor son, junior Periakaruppa, obtained Rs. 75,000 each and Alagappas wife Muthayi Achi, the mother of the minor son and his next friend in the suit, was to get a sum of Rs. 14,000 as her Stridhan, These amounts were paid by means of four hundis, Rs. 25,000 and Rs. 50,000 for Alagappa, Rs. 75,000 for junior Periakaruppa and Rs. 14,000 for the mother, Muthayi Achi, on Nattukottai Chetti bankers of Periakaruppa in Burma.

precedents.citation: Nidhoomoni Debya v. Saroda Pershad Mookerjee 1

anchor.surface_text: viz., Nidhoomoni Debya v. Saroda Pershad Mookerjee 1  and Fanindra Deb Raikat v. Rajeshwar Das 2  . As pointed out in the first case the question in all such cases is whether the gift of the property by the testator to a person who is referred to as having been adopted is one which is dependent on whether all the requisites of a valid adoption have been complied with or whether it is to a designated person notwithstanding that it was desired and expected that the requisites for a valid adoption were complied with.

precedents.case_name: Nidhoomoni Debya v. Saroda Pershad Mookerjee
precedents.cited_proposition: gift to person referred to as adopted son may be independent of validity of adoption
precedents.cited_holding: question is whether gift dependent on valid adoption or to designated person notwithstanding

precedents.citation: Fanindra Deb Raikat v. Rajeshwar Das 2

anchor.surface_text: Fanindra Deb Raikat v. Rajeshwar Das 2  . As pointed out in the first case the question in all such cases is whether the gift of the property by the testator to a person who is referred to as having been adopted is one which is dependent on whether all the requisites of a valid adoption have been complied with or whether it is to a designated person notwithstanding that it was desired and expected that the requisites for a valid adoption were complied with. As pointed out by their Lordships in the second case the distinction between what is description only and what is the reason or motive of a gift or bequest may often be very fine, but it is a distinction which must be drawn from a consideration of the language and the surrounding circumstances.

precedents.case_name: Fanindra Deb Raikat v. Rajeshwar Das
precedents.cited_proposition: distinction between description only and reason/motive of gift must be drawn from language and circumstances
precedents.cited_holding: distinction between description and motive may be fine but drawn from language and circumstances; illustration of gift to 'wife' despite invalid marriage

anchor.surface_text: Privy Council in Arunachalam v. Vairavan 1  and in Muthuraman v. Periannan 2 . In view of these decisions and the fact to which our attention has been drawn that there is no pleading in this case as to the meaning of the word maral or that the word order in the context of this case has been used in the sense A.I.R. 1929 P.C. 254, 256.

precedents.cited_proposition: meaning of 'maral' depends on proof of usage in each case

anchor.surface_text: in Muthuraman v. Periannan 2 . In view of these decisions and the fact to which our attention has been drawn that there is no pleading in this case as to the meaning of the word maral or that the word order in the context of this case has been used in the sense A.I.R, 1934 Mad. 621, 622. of maral, we are not prepared to uphold the contention that the word order in this case can be given the meaning which is attributed to the word maral in some of the cases which have been cited to us for the appellant.

precedents.cited_proposition: meaning of 'maral' depends on proof of usage in each case

precedents.citation: Krishnashet bin Ganshet Shetye v. Hari Valjibhatye 1

anchor.surface_text: as held in Krishnashet bin Ganshet Shetye v. Hari Valjibhatye 1 , the Negotiable Instruments Act,  in the absence of any local usage to the contrary  applies to hundis, what is urged above may well be applicable to the money of the original hundi for Rs. 75,000 drawn on Muthiah Chetti and specifically payable on demand to the order of the three persons, Alagappa, Muthayi Achi and Chockalingam.

precedents.case_name: Krishnashet bin Ganshet Shetye v. Hari Valjibhatye
precedents.cited_proposition: Negotiable Instruments Act applies to hundis absent local usage to contrary

anchor.surface_text: On the other hand there appears to, be authority to the contrary. See Sethna v. Hemmingway 1  and In re Travancore National and Quilon Bank Ltd. 1 . Both these cases indicate that a deposit receipt is not a negotiable instrument.

precedents.cited_proposition: deposit receipt is not a negotiable instrument

precedents.citation: In re Travancore National and Quilon Bank Ltd. 1

anchor.surface_text: See Sethna v. Hemmingway 1  and In re Travancore National and Quilon Bank Ltd. 1 . Both these cases indicate that a deposit receipt is not a negotiable instrument. It is true that in the language of the hundi, at both places, i.e.,  1  where the hundi is to be cashed, and  2  at the place where the cash so collected is to be invested, the same word order is used with reference to different sets of persons.

precedents.case_name: In re Travancore National and Quilon Bank Ltd.
precedents.cited_proposition: deposit receipt is not a negotiable instrument

anchor.surface_text: This appeal, i.e., Civil Appeal No. 169 of 1956, is accordingly allowed with costs throughout and the plaintiffs suit dismissed.

outcome.relief_summary: Civil Appeal No. 169 of 1956 (succession appeal) allowed; plaintiff's suit dismissed
